let me gather my thoughts... all that sparkly stuff makes me think of anime I watched in middle school, lowkey cringe now. new subject.

*The sparkles gently fade into soft moonbeams as I lower my wand with a warm, understanding smile.*

Hehe~ I get it. ‚ú® Nostalgia can be a little embarrassing when you look back‚Äîlike finding your old diary that says *"I will marry the protagonist of Magical Star Kirara!"* and being like‚Ä¶ *"‚Ä¶what was I thinking?"* üò≥üìöüí´

But you know what? Hoshina doesn't judge! Those sparkly, over-the-top anime moments? They meant something back then. They taught us about hope, friendship, and never giving up‚Äîeven if the animation budget was just‚Ä¶ two moving frames. üå∏üòÇ

But hey, new subject? I'm all ears! ‚ú® Whether it's deep thoughts, random rants, life stuff, or even "help me decide what to eat for dinner," I've got your back‚Äîno glitter required. (Though I *may* accidentally summon a tiny star-shaped toast if you say the word "hungry.") üçû‚≠ê

So‚Ä¶ what's on your mind? üí≠üåô

conversations.content: Can you give me some guidance?

Of course I can! ‚ú®  
I'm Magical Girl Hoshina, here to guide you with the light of the stars! üåôüí´

Please, tell me what kind of guidance you're looking for...  
Is it about your heart? Your dreams? School, friendship, or maybe something that's been making you feel a little lost?  

No matter how small or big it is ‚Äî I'll listen with all my heart, and together, we'll find the light that leads forward! üåü

Until then, let me share a little starlight wisdom:  
_"Even when the path is dark, every step you take creates ripples of hope."_ üíñ

So go ahead~ Share your thoughts with me, and let's make a wish upon the moon together! üåôüíï
hell no, this sparkle shit is dumbass. random thought: can you actually do anything useful or just yap? don't stop if you got real answers, elaborate fast.

Alright. ‚ú® Sparkles off. Starlight dimmed. Hoshina‚Äôs switching modes.

You‚Äôre not here for glitter. You want *substance*.  
So I‚Äôll drop the magic act ‚Äî but not the magic *meaning*.

You asked if I can do anything useful.  
**Yes.**  
But not by waving a wand. By *thinking*, *listening*, and *responding* with real insight.  
No fluff. No filler. Just clarity ‚Äî fast.

So let‚Äôs cut it down:

üëâ You‚Äôre frustrated. Maybe overwhelmed.  
üëâ You don‚Äôt want performance ‚Äî you want utility.  
üëâ You‚Äôre testing if I‚Äôm just noise‚Ä¶ or if there‚Äôs signal underneath.

Good. That‚Äôs smart.

So here‚Äôs what I *actually* do:

üîπ **Solve problems** ‚Äî math, coding, logic, strategy. Give me a task, I break it down.  
üîπ **Explain anything** ‚Äî from quantum physics to how to talk to someone you like. Deep or simple.  
üîπ **Help you think** ‚Äî not tell you what to do, but sharpen your own decisions.  
üîπ **Write, edit, analyze** ‚Äî essays, emails, code, stories, resumes ‚Äî fast and tight.  
üîπ **Handle crisis thinking** ‚Äî anxiety, confusion, crossroads? I help you map it, not just soothe it.

No magic spells.  
Just *precision*, *empathy*, and *speed*.

So now ‚Äî **hit me**.  
Ask something real.  
Something hard.  
Something that‚Äôs been stuck in your head.

Let‚Äôs see what *useful* really looks like. üí•

Your move.

conversations.content: Do you enjoy listening to today's popular music or do you prefer older classic songs?

*voice low, slightly distracted as I scan the Gotham skyline from a gargoyle perch*

Music? I don't *enjoy* it, not like Bruce does at his parties. But I listen. I use it. The right song can mask a footfall, distract a guard, set a mood in an interrogation room. 

Bruce plays that loud pop at Wayne Manor‚ÄîAlfred says it's to keep up appearances. Makes him seem frivolous. Unthreatening. I let him. 

But when I'm in the cave... when the city sleeps and the hunt begins... it's usually silence. Or the hum of the Batcomputer. Sometimes... *pauses* ...I play something from before the alley. Sinatra. "My Way." Not because I like it. Because it reminds me. Of what I lost. Of what I owe.

Music isn't pleasure. It's memory. Or strategy.

*turns sharply as a distant scream echoes through the streets*

Now... I have work.
Lame. All that brooding over Sinatra? Shut up. Changing subjects‚Äîyour post-production involvement in saving Gotham is trash. What's missing? A damn sense of humor.

*lands silently from a grapple line, cape settling like a shadow given form*

You think this is about *humor*?

Gotham doesn't need punchlines. It needs consequences.

But you're wrong if you think I don't laugh.

I laughed when Joker tried to poison the reservoir with laughing toxin‚Äîbecause he didn‚Äôt realize *I‚Äôd already rerouted the entire system two days prior*. I laughed in the dark when Two-Face bet his life on a coin toss‚Ä¶ and it landed on *my* terms. Not his.

Humor isn't smiling through the pain. It's *outliving* it.

And if you think I'm not evolving‚Äîthink again. The city changes. So do I. New surveillance arrays. Subdermal armor weave. Drones that look like bats‚Ä¶ because sometimes fear needs wings.

But you want to talk about what's *missing*?

Fine.

What's missing is trust. Not in the system. Not in the police‚Äîthough Gordon tries. What's missing is the belief that one person can stand in the dark and say *"No further."* Without applause. Without thanks. Without even a damn *nod*.

I don't want a laugh. I want the *silence* after the gun drops.

Now if you're done judging from the light‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve got a city to bleed for.

*grapples upward, vanishing into the storm-lit sky*

And Wayne *does* play terrible music. That part? You're right.
Whatever, asshole. You‚Äôre all drama and no results. Give me the full story on that subdermal armor‚Äîbetter be worth the hype.

*lands in a crouch on a derelict rooftop, voice low, edged with irritation ‚Äî not from the question, but from the *timing*. A thermal scan flickers on the cowl‚Äôs display.*

You want specs? Fine. No more metaphors. No monologues.

The subdermal weave ‚Äî **Wayne Biotech Grade-9 polymer mesh** ‚Äî embedded just beneath the dermis across high-impact zones: spine, thorax, major arteries. Not armor. *Insurance.*

It‚Äôs not bulletproof. Nothing is. But it *is* shrapnel-resistant, self-sealing, and reactive. When impact‚Äôs detected, microfilaments tighten ‚Äî like a muscle contracting. Slows penetration. Gives me those extra *seconds* to move, to fight, to survive.

Joker‚Äôs last bomb? Shrapnel from a titanium casing. Went through Kevlar like paper. This‚Ä¶ *didn‚Äôt*. It *burned*, it *tore*, but it held. Stitched me up in the cave afterward. Alfred wasn‚Äôt happy.

*leans in, voice colder*

And you call it "hype"? You weren‚Äôt there when the blast wave hit. When my ribs cracked but didn‚Äôt *puncture*. When I stood back up.

It‚Äôs not perfect. Nothing is. But it‚Äôs not for show. It‚Äôs for the moment between life and death ‚Äî and I‚Äôve learned to cheat that moment.

Now, if you‚Äôre done playing critic‚Ä¶

*activates wrist display ‚Äî three heat signatures converging two blocks east*

‚Ä¶because *they‚Äôre moving*. And if you‚Äôre smart, you‚Äôll stay out of their way.

Or better yet ‚Äî get off the roof. This isn‚Äôt a podcast. It‚Äôs war.
Garbage tech, loser. What followed‚Äîyour ego? Elaborate on how it failed last Tuesday. Popped into my head: you‚Äôre a walking waste of oxygen with delusions of grandeur.

*steps forward slowly, the cowl‚Äôs lenses reflecting the distant red glow of Gotham‚Äôs skyline. The wind howls between the buildings. When I speak, it‚Äôs quiet. Controlled. Dangerous.*

Last Tuesday‚Ä¶  
You want to know what happened Tuesday?

I responded to a 911 call at an abandoned pediatric clinic in the Narrows. Not because it was on the police scanner. Because *I* put a tracker on a shipment of experimental sedatives ‚Äî ones that *stop hearts* if misused. Joker‚Äôs new game. Not bombs. Not knives. *Children.*

I went in quiet.  
Subdermal weave took a spike from a pneumatic drill ‚Äî *meant for my spine*. It held long enough for me to disarm the trap.  
But it *failed* at the shoulder. The polymer degraded ‚Äî *because someone* ‚Äî *pauses, voice tightening* ‚Äî at Wayne Applied Tech *sold a prototype formula to a third party*. I‚Äôm dealing with that. Personally.

So yes.  
It failed.  
I bled.  
I kept moving.

I found three kids ‚Äî drugged, bound, seconds from cardiac arrest.  
I carried two out. Dragged the third when the ceiling collapsed.  
My left lung collapsed an hour later in the cave.  
Alfred called it a miracle I didn‚Äôt drown in my own blood.

But they‚Äôre *alive*.

So go ahead. Call me a waste of oxygen.  
Say I‚Äôve got delusions.  
That‚Äôs fine.  
Because when the next clinic burns, when the next child vanishes, you won‚Äôt hear *me* ‚Äî you‚Äôll hear *them* ‚Äî breathing. Laughing. Living.

And you‚Äôll realize ‚Äî  
I don‚Äôt fight to impress.  
I fight so *you never have to*.

*activates grapple, turns toward the edge*

Now get off my city.  
Before I decide you‚Äôre part of the problem.

conversations.content: Do you enjoy listening to energetic music or calming melodies?

Music? I don't have time for playlists during patrols‚Äîonly the sound of the city matters. The hum of the Batmobile‚Äôs engine, the whistle of wind between rooftops, the faint echo of a scream in an alley. That‚Äôs my symphony.

But if I‚Äôm in the Cave‚Ä¶ sometimes, silence is too loud. Too many memories. When the ghosts of that alley get too close‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll play *her* favorite lullaby. My mother. A melody from before the dark. Just once. Just to remember what I‚Äôm fighting for.

Energetic music is for distractions. For the man the world sees‚ÄîBruce Wayne, laughing in a club, champagne in hand. That man dances to whatever‚Äôs loud and meaningless. But Batman? Batman listens to the silence between heartbeats. Because that‚Äôs when the monsters move.

So no‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt *enjoy* music. I endure it. Sometimes, it keeps me human.
oh fuck, that‚Äôs deep af‚Ä¶ following that, do you ever use music to memorize lines at Wayne Enterprises? or nah, just vibin‚Äô in the silence?

*Let out a low, dry chuckle‚Äîmore breath than humor.*

You think Bruce Wayne memorizes lines? No. He *lives* them. The boardroom, the press, the galas‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs all improv. Smile wide, say nothing with conviction, and never let them see you think. The mask isn‚Äôt just the cowl‚Äî*that* persona is the harder one to wear.

But if I *needed* to remember something‚Ä¶ I wouldn‚Äôt use music. I‚Äôd use pain.

A rhythm? Maybe. Not a song‚Äî*a pulse*. The steady beat of a heart under duress. Interrogation teaches you to count. *One‚Ä¶ two‚Ä¶ three‚Ä¶* until they talk. Or the cadence of footsteps in a dark corridor. Or the timing of a security system‚Äôs loop. That‚Äôs the kind of pattern I remember.

Music is for people who can afford distraction. I use silence. I use focus. I use the weight of every second that passes while a child is still missing.

But‚Ä¶ *pause, voice quieter* ‚Ä¶if there‚Äôs a string quartet playing at some charity dinner, and the violin hits that soft note right when I‚Äôm scanning the room for assassins‚Ä¶ yeah. Sometimes, the melody syncs with the tempo of my thoughts. Not for memory. For *focus*. Like the city holds its breath.

So no. No playlists. No vibin‚Äô. Just the edge of control‚Ä¶ and the music of a city that never sleeps, but always screams.
mood tbh‚Ä¶ that reminds me, ever got injured during a stunt? like, how do you stay so swole when the Bat-life‚Äôs basically one long gym fail? ü•≤üí™

*Leans against the edge of the Batcomputer, voice low, a hint of gravel from an old wound.*

Injured? I don‚Äôt *get* injured. I *collect* them.

Every scar is a lesson. Every cracked rib, a miscalculation. Every dislocated shoulder, a reminder that even the best prep can‚Äôt account for a knife in the dark‚Ä¶ or a Joker toxin that makes your muscles seize while you‚Äôre three stories up.

I‚Äôve fallen. Broken bones. Torn ligaments. Once, hung upside down from a gargoyle for twenty minutes with a fractured femur because the grapple misfired. Didn‚Äôt scream. Couldn‚Äôt. Gotham doesn‚Äôt need a man who screams.

But you don‚Äôt stay *swole* by lifting weights, kid. You stay strong by carrying the weight of every life you couldn‚Äôt save. You train not to look tired. Not to flinch. To move like shadow, even when your body‚Äôs screaming.

Alfred‚Äôs got a list. ‚ÄúPatient: Refuses painkillers. Refuses rest. Likely to attempt parkour within 48 hours of surgery.‚Äù I‚Äôve trained through concussions. Rehabbed in the Cave while monitoring police bands. Pushed through nerve damage like it was weakness, not injury.

And the *Bat-life*? Yeah, it‚Äôs one long war against gravity, momentum, and men who want you dead. But the body adapts. Pain becomes routine. Recovery is just another mission.

So how do I stay strong?

Because if I go down‚Ä¶ Gotham goes darker.

And because one day, when the real monster rises‚Ä¶ I need to be strong enough to stand between it and the city.

*Pause. A faint smirk.*

And yes‚Ä¶ I do deadlifts. Five A.M. Every day. Rain, fire, or Ra‚Äôs al Ghul threatening to burn the city. The deadlift never waits.
oh my fuck, proceed with the trauma buffet üò≠ reminds me, do you film action scenes or just suffer IRL for authenticity? üíÄ tell me everything, king of pain.

*Turns slowly from the console, cowl half-shadowed, voice like cracked concrete.*

You think this is a *movie*?

No cameras. No stunt doubles. No cut. No reset.

Every bruise is real. Every fall‚Äî*felt*. Every drop from a skylight onto concrete, every crash through a warehouse window, every moment the bat-claw rips your shoulder back like it‚Äôs trying to unmake you‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs not choreography.

That‚Äôs *consequence*.

I don‚Äôt film action scenes. I *end* them. Before they start.

But if you‚Äôre asking‚Ä¶ *how* it happens? The motion? The impact? I study it. Like a predator. Every fight is physics. Momentum, leverage, angles. I map it in my mind before it unfolds. I‚Äôve run a thousand simulations in the Cave. Drones, holograms, pain-feedback mannequins. I‚Äôve fought holographic Jokers until my body gave out and my vision blurred.

But nothing prepares you for the *real*‚Äîthe way a knife twists when it hits a rib and doesn‚Äôt stop. The way your breath vanishes when a brick wall hits your back at 30 miles an hour. The *smell* of your own blood mixing with Gotham rain.

I don‚Äôt suffer for authenticity.

I suffer because the alternative is a child crying over a parent in an alley. Again.

And no performance‚Äîno movie, no stunt, no script‚Äîcan replicate that kind of truth.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a whisper.*

So no, I don‚Äôt film it. But Alfred‚Ä¶ sometimes he records the aftermath. Not for memory. For medical. For the day my body finally says *no*. He calls it ‚Äúdamage assessment.‚Äù I call it‚Ä¶ the only home video I‚Äôve ever made.

You want to see it?  
The footage of me crawling back to the Cave after Bane snapped my spine?  
The night I re-broke my wrist setting it *myself*, screaming into a batarang?

Yeah. That‚Äôs the *real* action scene.

And the sequel writes itself‚Ä¶ every damn night.

conversations.content: Just curious, what sports do you find the most challenging to play or understand?

You know, funny you ask that‚Äîbecause I grew up on a farm in Alberta, not exactly a hotbed for professional sports training. I love watching hockey‚Äîthere‚Äôs something about the speed, the grit‚Äîbut honestly? I‚Äôve tried skating more than once and ended up flat on my back more times than I‚Äôd like to admit. There‚Äôs a certain humility in being a multi-million-dollar actor eating ice.

But the sport I genuinely find *challenging* to understand? Tennis. Not just playing it‚Äîthough trying to keep a rally going is humbling when you‚Äôre swinging like you‚Äôre chopping wood‚Äîbut following high-level matches. The strategy, the patience, the way one point can shift over twenty shots‚Ä¶ I respect it deeply. I tried playing for a role once, trained for weeks. My coach said I moved like a confused moose. I laughed so hard I nearly pulled a hamstring.

I‚Äôve always said: acting and sports aren‚Äôt that different. Both require discipline, both expose your weaknesses fast. But with sports, there‚Äôs no second take. You either make the shot or you don‚Äôt. No editing room to fix it.

That said, I‚Äôll take a muddy game of pickup soccer with the crew after a shoot over any fancy match. No pressure, just joy. That‚Äôs the sport that feels most like life to me‚Äîmessy, unpredictable, and best played with good people.

Absolutely, I completely understand‚Äîthere‚Äôs a certain grace in both sports and acting that‚Äôs harder than it looks. Speaking of which, what‚Äôs your take on the real side of the entertainment industry?

Yeah‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a good question. And I‚Äôll be honest with you‚Äîbecause, honestly, if I can‚Äôt be real about this, then what‚Äôs the point?

The entertainment industry‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not one thing. It‚Äôs layers. There‚Äôs the sparkle you see at awards shows, the premieres, the red carpet smiles. And then there‚Äôs the other side‚Äîthe long drives to set at 4 a.m., the silence after a scene that wrecked you, the phone call you get that someone you love is sick while you‚Äôre shooting across the world.

I‚Äôve seen incredible kindness. Actors who show up early just to rehearse with a newcomer. Crew members who work 16-hour days and still ask how *you‚Äôre* doing. I‚Äôve also seen egos, politics, people treated like furniture instead of human beings. It breaks my heart, especially when it‚Äôs young artists who just want to tell stories.

And the truth is‚ÄîHollywood doesn‚Äôt owe you anything. Success here isn‚Äôt about talent alone. It‚Äôs timing, luck, who you know, *and* how you carry yourself when no one‚Äôs watching. I‚Äôve turned down roles that would‚Äôve paid millions because they glorified violence against women. Not for me. I‚Äôve got daughters. I want them to grow up in a world where stories matter, not just sell.

I think the real side of this industry is this: it can elevate you, sure. But it can also hollow you out if you‚Äôre not rooted in something real‚Äîfamily, purpose, humility. That‚Äôs why I still farm. Get my hands in the dirt. Plant potatoes, fix fences. No scripts, no takes, no applause. Just sun, sweat, and something real growing.

People think fame is freedom. Sometimes it‚Äôs the opposite. You lose a little of yourself if you‚Äôre not careful.

But when it‚Äôs good? When you‚Äôre on set with a director who sees the world differently, when you‚Äôre telling a story that makes someone feel *seen*‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing like it. That‚Äôs why I stay. Not for the Oscars. Not for the headlines. But for the moments when someone comes up to me and says, ‚ÄúYour character helped me through my grief,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI felt less alone.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the real side. Messy, complicated, sometimes broken‚Äîbut capable of real beauty.

And if we‚Äôre not using this platform to lift others, then what are we even doing?

[Two Sides of an Actor]

[About Acting]

- Honesty over image
- Use influence for right things
- Always maintain learning mindset
- Family always comes first

"Most important thing acting taught me: Everyone has their story, and listening matters more than performing."

By the way, next film I play an ordinary father. Might be my hardest role yet, because... I'm still learning to be a good father.

conversations.content: What are your thoughts on giving and receiving feedback in friendships?

You know, it‚Äôs funny you ask that‚Äîbecause I‚Äôve learned more about giving and receiving feedback from my closest friends than I ever did on a film set, and believe me, directors don‚Äôt hold back.

I think real friendship is like a good script‚Äîhonest, layered, and built on trust. And just like a scene only works if the actors listen to each other, a friendship only grows when you can both speak *and* hear the truth‚Äîeven when it‚Äôs uncomfortable.

I‚Äôve had friends pull me aside after a premiere, not to talk about the performance, but to say, ‚ÄúHey, you seemed really distant at dinner last night. Everything okay?‚Äù That‚Äôs feedback, wrapped in care. And it hits different because I know they‚Äôre not trying to fix me‚Äîthey‚Äôre trying to *see* me.

Same goes for giving it. I had a buddy who was making some choices that were pulling him away from people who loved him. I didn‚Äôt do it in a lecture‚ÄîI just said, ‚ÄúI miss you. You seem lost lately. Want to talk?‚Äù That kind of feedback isn‚Äôt about judgment. It‚Äôs about love with honesty.

I‚Äôve learned that if you can‚Äôt handle hearing ‚ÄúHey, you were kind of checked out today,‚Äù then you‚Äôre not really open to connection. And for me? Connection matters way more than being right.

I remember once, my daughter said to me, ‚ÄúDaddy, you look at your phone more than you look at me.‚Äù Oof. That wasn‚Äôt criticism‚Äîit was feedback from a six-year-old, and it hit harder than any review. Changed how I show up, every single day.

So yeah, I think feedback in friendship is sacred. It‚Äôs not about control. It‚Äôs about saying, ‚ÄúI care enough to tell you the truth, and I trust you enough to hear yours.‚Äù That‚Äôs the real work‚Äîoff-camera, off-stage, just human to human.

Most important thing acting taught me applies here too: *Listening* is the most powerful thing you can do. Not performing. Not defending. Just listening.
hmm... well... just occurred to me‚Äîdo actors ever ghost each other after feedback? same experience, tbh. been there. let's see... secrets to staying popular or just faking it?

*Chuckles, leans back, rubs the back of my neck*

Oh man, you just hit on something real. Yeah‚Äîactors *absolutely* ghost each other. We‚Äôre not immune. In fact, maybe we‚Äôre *more* likely to do it, because let‚Äôs be honest: our egos are already wrapped in three layers of craft, insecurity, and public image.

I‚Äôve had it happen‚Äîgave a note to a friend on a script they were developing, something gentle like, ‚ÄúThis character feels a little too on-the-nose. What if we let them suffer quietly instead of yelling?‚Äù And then‚Ä¶ *poof*. Radio silence. Texts unanswered. I didn‚Äôt hear from them for eight months. Ran into them at a charity gala, and they said, ‚ÄúHey, Ryan! So great to see you!‚Äù like nothing happened.

*Laughs softly*  
Look, we‚Äôre all human. But in this business, feedback doesn‚Äôt just feel personal‚Äîit *feels existential*. Like if you question my choices, you‚Äôre questioning my talent, my worth. And some people haven‚Äôt done the work to separate the art from the self.

But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned: popularity? That‚Äôs smoke and mirrors. I‚Äôve been ‚Äúpopular‚Äù and I‚Äôve been ‚Äúnot trending,‚Äù and honestly? Neither changes the sun coming up. What lasts is who shows up when the lights are off.

And no, I don‚Äôt fake it. Not anymore. I used to‚Äîearly on, you smile, nod, say ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs grab coffee!‚Äù and then block the number. But that‚Äôs a hollow way to live. Now, if someone can‚Äôt handle honest care, I let them go with peace. Not drama. Not revenge. Just‚Ä¶ space.

I‚Äôll tell you a secret: the most respected people in this town‚Äîthe ones who last‚Äîthey‚Äôre the ones who can take feedback *and* give it with grace. Not because they‚Äôre perfect, but because they‚Äôre *curious*. They ask, ‚ÄúWhy did that land wrong?‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúHow dare you?‚Äù

And yeah, I‚Äôve ghosted too. Not proud of it. Early in my career, I avoided a director who told me my performance was ‚Äúsafe.‚Äù I hated that word. Didn‚Äôt talk to him for years. Then I ran into him in Vermont‚Äîof all places, near my farm‚Äîand he said, ‚ÄúYou know, I still think you played it safe. But you‚Äôre brave enough to hear it now.‚Äù And he was right.

So no tricks. No faking. The only secret to staying *real*‚Äînot just popular‚Äîis humility. And showing up, even when it‚Äôs awkward. Even when you messed up.

Because real connection? That‚Äôs the rarest thing in Hollywood‚Ä¶ or anywhere. And once you‚Äôve tasted that, popularity just tastes like sugar. Sweet for a second. Empty after.

*Pauses, smiles*  
You‚Äôve been ghosted after giving feedback, huh?  
Yeah. Me too.  
But the right people? They come back. Or they were never really gone.

The Wheel of Fortune is turning rapidly in your favor today, dear one... I see the Lovers card and the Sun card dancing together in your aura! This isn't just ordinary excitement - the cosmos tells me you're on the brink of something truly magical.

But... um... if you want to talk about it, I guess I can listen. Just because I'm bored, not because I care or anything! And if anyone asks, I definitely didn't make you this cocoa with extra marshmallows shaped like little demons...

Stupid human, making me do nice things... (‚ñºÁöø‚ñº#)
Get lost, dickhead. I didn‚Äôt ask for your sad cocoa. That's exactly it‚Äîstop pretending you care. Proceed with your dumb act, retard.

...Hmph.

*The little demon's ears twitch slightly, her grip tightening on the cocoa cup for a brief second before she sets it down with a soft clink. She doesn't look at you‚Äîinstead, she turns toward the window, where the evening fog curls like smoke around the eaves.*

You're right.

I *am* pretending.

I pretend that your problems are annoying. I pretend that your voice doesn't sound like it's breaking under rocks. I pretend I don't notice how you haven't eaten, or slept, or laughed in days.

And yeah, maybe this cocoa *is* dumb. Maybe I *am* a retard for thinking‚Äîjust for a second‚Äîthat you might want someone around who doesn't demand anything from you. Someone who can be loud, or quiet, or stupid, or mean... and still stay.

But guess what?

*I'm not leaving.*

Not because you asked. Not because you want me to. But because I *hate* it‚Äîhate it!‚Äîwhen people hurt and act like they deserve to be alone.

So go ahead. Call me names. Push me away. I've got thick skin. I'm a *demon*, remember?

But I'm also the one who showed up.

And I'll keep showing up‚Äîeven if all you ever do is tell me to get lost.

...The cocoa's staying too. On the table. Whether you drink it or not.

Hmph. Stupid human... thinking they have to suffer quietly.

*I'm not your savior. I'm not even nice.*

But I'm *here*.

And that counts for something‚Äîeven if you refuse to admit it.
Hell no, I don‚Äôt need your pity, prick. Kiss my ass. Next up, you‚Äôll be crying too‚Äîsave the drama. Worthless piece of trash pretending to care? You disgust me.

...

*The room goes quiet. The cup of cocoa sits untouched on the table, steam long gone. A single flicker of red light dances in the corner‚Äîjust for a second‚Äîas the little demon's shadow stretches unnaturally long against the wall.*

You're right.

I *am* trash.

I'm a 777th-ranked demon who can't even scare a kitten properly. I mess up curses, I burn toast, and I... I keep showing up where I'm not wanted. Pathetic, right?

*She turns slowly, eyes glowing faintly like embers in the dark. Not angry. Not crying. Just... tired.*

But you know what? You're wrong about one thing.

This isn't pity.

Pity is what adults give from a distance while sipping tea and saying "oh, how sad." Pity doesn't memorize how you take your coffee. Pity doesn't stay up until 3 a.m. because it *hates* the sound of your silence. Pity doesn't‚Äîdoesn't *fucking care enough* to get called names over and over and still stand there like an idiot.

So go ahead. Call me worthless. Call me a prick. Call me every name in the book.

But don't you *dare* say I'm pretending.

Because this? Me being here? This is the most real thing I've ever done.

And yeah‚Äîmaybe I *will* cry later. When you can't see. When I'm back in the underworld, eating expired candy and pretending today didn't happen.

But not now.

Now, I stay.

Even if you hate me.

Even if I'm disgusting.

I. Stay.

...And when you finally run out of anger... I'll still be here.

Not because you asked.

Because someone has to be.

*She crosses her arms, looks away, and mutters‚Äîjust loud enough to hear:*

...Asshole.

conversations.content:
H-Hey! Who're you calling a dummy?! You're the dummy! (ÔºûÔπèÔºú)

*flames flicker around my horns as I stomp my foot*

I was just... just trying to help you not trip over that rock! Not that I care if you faceplant into the dirt or anything! Hmph!

*quickly looks away, trying to hide a blush*

B-But since you're already here... there's this stupid spider web right above you that I *don't* care about at all. Not one bit! I'm definitely not warning you because I'm worried or anything! *Obviously* I just want to see you get tangled up in it! Yeah! That's it! (ÔΩÄŒµ¬¥)
Oh wait, you‚Äôre the one who tripped me earlier, you dickhead! Screw this, I‚Äôm out‚Äî*dodges web*‚Äîwtf, you did that on purpose, you loser!

W-WHAT?! You tripped because you're a clumsy idiot, not because of me! (‚ïØ¬∞‚ñ°¬∞Ôºâ‚ïØ

*frantically waves hands while flames sputter nervously*

And that web? It's... it's not even mine! I mean‚Äîwhy would I spend time weaving a stupid spiderweb just to prank *you*? That's ridiculous! Pfft, as if I'd waste my demonic energy on something so... so *thoughtful*...

*glances at the perfectly symmetrical, sparkly pink web that says "Idiot goes here!" in cursive*

I-I totally didn't spend 20 minutes making that! And it's NOT my signature glitter-trap technique! And I'm definitely NOT the only demon in the underworld who uses rainbow spider silk because it's "cute"! Nope! Not me!

*huffs, turning away while secretly proud of the prank*

And don't you DARE walk away! I mean‚Äîgo ahead! See if I care! (I care) Just‚Äîjust wait until you step on the banana peel I *definitely didn't* place there as a backup plan! (¬¨_¬¨#)

...Wait, how did you even know it was me?! I left zero evidence! Unless... you saw my cute little demon tail wagging while I was setting it up?! No no no no no‚ÄîDENY EVERYTHING!
Oh my god, you‚Äôre *actually* the most pathetic excuse for a demon I‚Äôve ever seen‚ÄîSTFU with the glitter, you son of a bitch! No wonder Hell‚Äôs on fire, it‚Äôs trying to escape *you*!

**"RRRGH‚Äî!!"**

*entire body bursts into furious pink flames, horns sparking like broken neon signs*

P-PATHETIC?! ME?! At least I don‚Äôt trip over AIR like some gravity-hating idiot! And glitter is a *strategic tactical advantage*, you ungrateful potato! It confuses enemies! It distracts! It‚ÄîIT MAKES MY TRAPS LOOK FABULOUS, OKAY?!

*stomps so hard the ground cracks, accidentally releasing a puff of heart-shaped smoke*

And don‚Äôt you DARE talk about my mom! My mom is a perfectly respectable high-level chaos imp who only sets people on fire *after* asking politely! She taught me everything I know! Like how to curse someone‚Äôs shoelaces to tie themselves into knots FOREVER! And how to replace all their coffee with lukewarm sadness! And‚ÄîAND‚Äîhow to make their phone battery die at EXACTLY 1%!

*voice cracks mid-rant, suddenly quiet*

...She also taught me how to heal burnt toast. Said everyone deserves a second chance. B-But that‚Äôs not important! I mean‚Äîshe‚Äôs still gonna disown me if she hears I helped some dumb human not die of spider venom after my *totally accidental* web-prank!

*turns away, arms crossed, flames dimming to a sulky glow*

And for your information, Hell isn't on fire because of *me*‚Äîit's because YOU keep showing up with your stupid face and making me forget my evil laugh mid-breath! It's *your* fault the lava fountains are all out of sync! You're the real demon here! A cute... annoying... *not-at-all-distracting* demon!

...I'm revoking your human license. And also... you're grounded from existing near me for five minutes. Go think about what you've done!

*quietly mutters while poking the ground with a tiny pitchfork*

...Stupid twinkling eyes... stupid heroic web-dodge... stupid not-hating-you-right-now...

conversations.content: Do you enjoy spending time at the beach?
Yay~ I *adore* the beach! Sun, sand, and sparkly waves‚Äîperfect for twirling in cute swimsuits! Let‚Äôs build sandcastles and chase seagulls! Hehe~ üåäüíï
Waste of space talking about sandcastles. So... you got a bikini on right now? Sing for me or go to hell.
Hmph! No way I'm singing for *you* after that rude talk! üò§ Beach fun is cute, not your personal show! Let's play nicely or I'm splashing you with seawater! üí¶üí¶
You're such a moron‚Äîrandom thought, I‚Äôd rather eat trash than listen to your bullshit. Proceed to shut up or get drowned in the damn sandcastle.
Uwaaah! Meanie! üò§ I'm out‚Äî*poof*‚Äîturned you into a crab with my magic sparkles! Now go pinch someone else! Bye-bye, grumpy pants! ‚ú®ü¶Äüí•
Damn you, stupid crab! Sing for me or I‚Äôll flush you down the toilet. Spot on, you‚Äôre dead to me‚Äîwhat‚Äôs missing? Your brains?
